Snoozing emails can also be such a trap', '11:31 Ali Abdaal from Active Learning videos: *RED LASER EYES*', '11:06 Aaaahh if this phrase was only a hyperbole... but it literally happened to me, and i think it will never be "cured", is just how the brain is programmed. I think i've memorized The Obstacle Is The Way almost entirely, everytime i ready it feels familiar and i know the next phrase likes pieces falling perfectly in place in a cascade (especially if i reread a couple of times after a layoff) but the problem is: i can't remember by my own! Everything comes fluidly reading out loud but if i had to recite from heart i would suddenly forget big chunks of it.

If you ever did singing classes - or simply sang with the music - you know how much more easier it to find the tone when the song is on or there's a coach is doing with you, but once he/she asks you to go by yourself... *gulp* you're in a bit of a pickle. That's because doing by yourself is much more harder and weaknesses of yours are exposed, you naturally start to notice things about yourself, about your pattern of thinking and your technique that you don't notice normally, there's much more presence and self awareness.

After using Active Recall in past few months i realized how much more different it is from passively reading, there's a more intense "imagery", you have to use much more brain power to remember and at times feels like you are physically exerting yourself to pull something. But your ideas feels more powerful, permanent, and this different feeling gives you confidence that you don't get with the old way (it's kinda common sense to be honest, like the principle of specificity in Power/Olyliftiing). I also started to wonder how much those apps might start getting in the way of actually getting things done. Yeah, you have an app that saves articles for later, but that doesn't mean it helps you get through the goal of actually reading the articles you save. To-do lists can be beneficial, but use them too rigidly; you won't want to do anything. Being productive definitely comes from an aspirational mindset, and using some (but probably not all) of the widgets can make a dredging experience more novel. That helps you get engaged with the task. Those things we don't actually want to do since we are cognitive misers and don't want to expend our mental faculties will probably benefit from a written goal with tangible evidence of completion (e.g., checking it off the list).

Simply put, you need two big things for productivity-- goals and habits. If you want to become productive, you need to set small goals that encourage your progression to a larger purpose, and you need good habits that keep you on track with those goals. The gizmos are just novel tools that can help and provide inspiration for new ideas. Learn where you can incorporate the ones you like and nix the rest. Changing your mindset and thinking more positively about the things you are doing will inevitably be more helpful, if not just to curtail stressors.', 'Really enjoyed this. I love playing with my work!', 'Here are the 5 things I took away from this video:
First, a quote: " if you can learn to enjoy the journey, if you can learn to have fun, then productivity takes care of iteself "

Tips:
1. Change your mindset - think to yourself "this will be fun" or "I get to do this" instead of "I have to do this"
2. Turn it into a game - how can you track your progress in a metric you have direct control over? how else could you gamify this task?
3. Do it with friends - either find ways to involve them in the project that makes it enjoyable and worth their time, or simply find a pleasant space to do work together
4. Craft a pleasant working environment - incorporate a pleasant aroma, clean workspace, organized materials, good lighting, your favorite beverage, headphones, music if you choose, and the tools you need within reach
5. Understand why you are doing the thing you are doing - how does it fit into an overall bigger part of the project? how does it help serve a higher purpose? how will it help you move closer toward one of your goals or objectives?

That's all. I hope you find this helpful. Cheers!', 'ğŸ‘', 'More reading in first advice is also about passion is Cal Newports' "The Passion Trap". Long story so prepare. (Not a native english speaker, sorry for my mistakes)

Finishing high school, I truly did not know what I want to do with my life. I just chose Computer Science, as an opportunity to earn "more than the average" and try to live abroad (I live in Kazakhstan). I mostly chose CS degree only because I spent a lot of time on my computer and playing video games, and did not have any other "passions". Went to my first University, and just failed 13 out of 14 courses. I was burnt out, had no directions in life, and genuinely gave up on trying to do something. Thankfully my parents helped me out and sent me to a psychotherapist. That was a small push, and directions I needed.

After months of trying to learn more about myself, I somewhat know what I would like to do with my life:

Plan A: Become a Singer
Plan B: Earn money by becoming a Game-Developer
Plan C: Multiply my money by trying out Investments

Plan A is the main plan, because singing makes me feel alive
Plan B and C go is what I will do if plan A won't work.

So to anyone there not knowing what to do in their life, I will advise you to learn more about yourself, and find things that are satisfying to you. Awesome video!! ğŸ‘ğŸ»ğŸ‘ğŸ»', 'As I am in the process of writing my own book based on the time management trainings I have developed and delivered, I'll share just a few extremely powerful thoughts: First, 'productivity' has absolutely nothing to with 'getting more things done'. (This a wide misconception, as vast numbers of people fill their lives with mountains of busy work, only to wind up with little to show for it.) Secondly, productivity has little to do with 'doing what is important'. (One's list of 'important' to-do's' is potentially infinite. Therefore, attempting to work through that list can also be potentially futile.) The key to true productivity is to begin to view time as a resource you are perpetually being forced to invest. You do not have a choice, one way or the other, as to whether, or not, you will invest your time. You will, as long as you are alive. You only have a choice regarding WHERE you invest it. Therefore, a sober and honest assessment of what your potential return on investment is likely to be should start to dictate how and where you spend your time. A good empowering question to ask is, "How is this action related to the fulfillment of my highest values and goals?" If something doesn't support your highest values, and the actual achievement of goals that are aligned with those values, you may want to question if it is an investment worthy of your time.', '5:21 I'm going to try this mindset right now :D Thank you Ali!', '11:16 so agree with this advice. When you're a caretaker and must feed, bathe and support others all day, I don't end up even showering some days, let alone work out. I don't even see the sky for a week sometimes. I don't sleep normal hours and must respond to others in the middle of the night, throwing off my sleep schedule. How can I 'schedule' anything when I'm sleeping until noon because I couldn't get back to sleep after being woken at 3am? I get up and am starving and everyone else wants feeding so I quickly drink my sports shake so I have the stamina to make others their food, first. It must be nice to be only responsible for yourself. I can't imagine what my life would be like if I didn't have anyone else to deal with - I suppose lonely? or, just busy doing my own stuff? If you consider the amount of work freelancers have to put in and the structural limitations they experience, I feel it's only fair to try to compensate them fairly for that, not just in relative terms, but in absolute value (or close to it) as well. I know this kind of advice comes from books like the 4-Hour Work Week, but honestly the ideas in that book have a very ruthless, outdated, almost neo-colonial vibe to them. Yes, inequalities exist and there's only so much we can do to fix them (to be clear I don't expect Ali to fix the problems of the world lol), and more often than not people will choose to take advantage of said inequality if it means making their lives easier. The reality is that that's become a norm, but honestly I wish that wasn't the case. I just worry that this piece of advice is such a recurring recommendation on your channel, especially in a time where people don't just need the bare minimum, but need empathy and any fair valuation of labor they can get. Especially considering the fact that developing countries are truly truly struggling to get back on their feet because to the pandemic. I know you don't mean any ill, Ali, and are just sharing what works for you. I just hope this kind of advice is delivered with a little more sensitivity or at least not given out without some kind of discussion of these realities. I am a longtime fan of your content and your channel, I just hope this constructive critique reaches you and perhaps serves as some food for thought. Thanks this is gold! ğŸ‘', 'Who is here to prograstinate', 'That force is an evil spirit', 'When the algorithm is more worried about you life than you.', 'Here's a 1-second solution. Really - it' takes one second. This works to eliminate writer's procrastination effortlessly for both fiction or non-fiction: Simply erase part of the last sentence you've written for that day. Your mind is hardwired to be working on it, so that you won't be able to wait for the earliest time to get back to writing some more. Do this every time. If your last sentence is so golden you don't want to erase it, write another line and erase part of it.\r
\r
If you're stuck and haven't written in a while, go back to where you left off and erase part of the last sentence you wrote.\r
Your last sentence might change almost every time. Who cares because you're on your way!\r
\r
IOW, you've just conquered the biggest challenge to writing for most writers and done it effortlessly.\r
\r
Kelley Eidem\r

Highly recommend if you like books like the mistborn series.', 'Is there a pill?', '- Ali stopped procrastinating after reading the War of Art\r
- Know the enemy: Resistance. Fear creates resistance which creates more fear and it becomes an increasingly stronger cycle.\r
- The solution is to interpret fear as a signal â€“ fear is your compass. The more scared you are of something, the more important it is to you.\r
- Become a Professional. A Pro understands fear and failure is part of the process, they show up to work no matter what, resistance is the daily battle. Conversely, an amateur's actions are mood-driven and goals are often extrinsic and hedonic (fun, money and status). \r
- Hence, also make sure your goals are process goals (i.e. upload 2 videos every week), which are things you can control vs. outcome goals (get 1 mil subscribers) which are nice and to be celebrated but not the point. Most of the things that he says here are going to make procrastination even worst. He kind of says some point right of course but again to sum up relies heavily on the notion of powering through that resistance.
BETTER WAY TO APPROACH PROCRASTINATION!!
If U feel resistance, focus on reducing the resistance and the load factor, not focus on increasing your effort.
Eg: If I don't feel like working today, its fine, I will just work for 1 hour today.. or 2 hours. U will most likely work longer than that but approach truly like its fine even if U worked just for 1 hour today.
Reduce your goal and the sense of how well the work has to be. Once U reduce this self afflicted burden of setting urself a high goal, the work automatically becomes less intimidating
If the work itself is very Twisted and difficult. Focus on simplifying it first. Focus on the simple stuff. Do it first. And for the rest of the work, Simplify and make it like manageable list of this and that and that.. the steps that U write be as simple as possible, that aim to detangle the complicated issue into more straighter, manageable steps.
You are not a procrastinator the way U approach the work leads U to that feeling of resistance, lighten Up Ur Aim, make it easy for yourself, focus on only task for next 1 hour, make things simpler, Ask yourself how can I do this task the most most easiest way...And voila.. See the magic happen.
And of course rely on a schedule rather than on motivation.', 'another attempt to fight myself and guess what I'm failing ğŸ˜Œ', 'does binge watching your videos comes under procrastination ? no offense.', 'my school sent me this video

- Ali stopped procrastinating after reading the War of Art
- Know the enemy: Resistance. Fear creates resistance which creates more fear and it becomes an increasingly stronger cycle.
- The solution is to interpret fear as a signal â€“ fear is your compass. The more scared you are of something, the more important it is to you.
- Become a Professional. A Pro understands fear and failure is part of the process, they show up to work no matter what, resistance is the daily battle. Conversely, an amateur's actions are mood-driven and goals are often extrinsic and hedonic (fun, money and status).
- Hence, also make sure your goals are process goals (i.e. upload 2 videos every week), which are things you can control vs. outcome goals (get 1 mil subscribers) which are nice and to be celebrated but not the point. â–ªï¸the first principle
Break it down.
No matter what you're trying to accomplish whether it's a writing a book or climbing a mountain the key to a achievement is your ability to break it down.and knock them off
one at a time. Also keep in mind to focus what is right in front of you and ignore what is off in the distance.
â–ªï¸the second principle.
Write it down
Instead of describing the things that you want to do and the places that you want to go describe what you actually did with your time buy a little book that you carry all the time when you study, when you go the lunch,when you go to the dry cleaner make a quick note the time you begun the activity and the time it ended.

It definitely resonates with me.', 'â˜˜ I just found you recently as I am endeavoring to utilize Notion as my 'life' dashboard. Trying to juggle sooo much and tired of forgetting all the pieces. lol. Anyway, yes, so important to be compassionate with ourselves in a balanced way of pushing past the uncomfortable to 'get where we want to go' (starting rituals and 'done is better than perfect' attitude to GTD help too)... and letting go of some 'good' things to make sure we have enough room for the 'better' stuff. Boundaries is a good newish word for me. Around my time and my energy. I've had to 'parent' myself around sleep. (I love knowing there is a term for the trap I fall into... 'revenge....??' lol.) Though sometime's I get stuck in a rabbit hole of research about good stuff and am up way too late. I realize I am not as productive as I think I am when I'm doing 'work' that gets in the way of a restorative nights sleep. Bottom line, we are all works in progress and we need to give ourselves a break and not beat us up when we fall short. Just keep going. Generally, our body is telling us when we need to realign our priorities by responding in the way you describe. Our central nervous system needs some attention. We go go go... and realize we are out of balance and without taking time for 'self care' routines. We will be forced by our natural physical response (pain, illness, fatigue, brain fog... etc.) to slow the heck down. I've spent a couple years dealing with CPTSD and trauma that I didn't know I had... until I 'shut down' and had to go on a path of discovery because I didn't want to remain in the state I was in. I think all of us need to come to a place of 'awareness' at some point in life in order to truly derive a sense of completion and satisfaction and connection to ourself and the world. A couple foundational books for me: 'The Artist's Way' (for every human and ESPECIALLY if you have already decided to take on a creative endeavor like writing a book)... The Body Keeps the Score (about how our body holds onto trauma... little or big... and how to release it). 'Doing the Work' by Dr. Nicole La Pera - even if you do not have trauma in your life... what you are talking about, being in touch and connected to yourself and dealing with self and others, this book helps us all get in better touch with ourselves. Recognize the discomfort we and others may feel through patterns of thought and behavior we may be unconscious about. Her Instagram as the 'Holistic Psychologist' help shift thought paradigms around and about dealing with ourselve and others. How to set better thought patterns and truly be our authentic selves and give space for others to do the same. Anyway, I truly am thankful for your 'verbal processing' videos as well as all of the helpful productivity shares you provide. Sharing what works for you (in real case application) is so helpful. I think as you keep doing what your 'gut' is telling you to do, even if it breaks a mold (especially if it does)... it will resonate with the folks who need it. Being 'real' and authentic helps other's realize they are not so different after all... we all can connect to each other's humaness and it creates a sense of community. Losing the enjoyment in things that you normally enjoy is one of the hallmarks of depression, which sounds ominous but isn't necessarily. My psychologist told me she started feeling depressed during covid due to "behaviour activation" not due to actually being depressed as such. Basically the change of working from home and not having to get up early or leave the house were behaviours that are normally symptoms of depression. This is so good and unique share.', 'If I am in UK , you are the first person I'll meet and Andrew Kirby , the second', 'Hey Ali, great video, love your honesty about this topic! So funny, because earlier this day I was thinking about my productivity system and how I see it:

The first step is time management when you start to play with scheduling and then observing and analyzing how things work for you. Then you start to notice that it's not all about your time, but about your mood, too.

This brings you to step 2, where you start doing mood management. You are trying to find out what & how influences your mood waves. You are working on how to successfully riding your waves of energy and trying to reduce the time when you are in curve dropping, so the drops are smaller and smaller.

But then it comes to step no. 3, which I call "holistic productivity". Here it's not only about work that has to be done, but connecting all your main "life areas" in a way you feel satisfied. Because even if you're productivity ninja during your work time, and then you are too tired to play with your kids, or without the energy for doing something you like, or you just don't feel satisfied with your day before you go to bed, in the long run, you'll become less productive. In this step, we understand we don't need to (or better we're not supposed to be) productive all the time, and be okay with that.

I believe the main goal is to find the balance between "working" and "being".

'Monks, these two extremes ought not to be practiced by one who has gone forth from the household life. What are the two? There is addiction to indulgence of sense-pleasures, which is low, coarse, the way of ordinary people, unworthy, and unprofitable; and there is addiction to self-mortification, which is painful, unworthy, and unprofitable. Avoiding both these extremes, the Tathagata has realized the Middle Path; it gives vision, gives knowledge, and leads to calm, to insight, to enlightenment and to Nibbana.' â€” Gautama Buddha

When you set firm resolutions to improve yourself, you might be tempted to push your limits well outside of what youâ€™re capable of doing. Ambitiousness is a virtue, but thereâ€™s danger involved in going from one extreme to another.

If youâ€™re currently struggling to be productive, donâ€™t force yourself to work sixteen hours a day. If youâ€™re struggling to control your appetite, donâ€™t impose a week-long fast. If you canâ€™t find it in you to choose the stairs over the elevator, donâ€™t expect that youâ€™ll maintain a workout plan that requires you to work out every single day.

Find the middle path, stick to it for at least several weeks, and then, based on the results you get, decide whether you can further stretch your limits or require more time before advancing.

As much as I believe in pushing your boundaries and exploring the extremes, you donâ€™t need to put yourself through mortification to achieve good results. Subjecting yourself to extreme hardships has some merits, but over the long term itâ€™s unsustainable, if not downright dangerous.

Remember that there should be moderation in all things, including moderation itself. Sometimes a more extreme approach is needed for a short period of time, and sometimes itâ€™s beneficial to set your goals lower. In whatever you do, seek to not spend too much time loafing around, but also make sure that your life hasnâ€™t turned into the life of a self-flagellating ascetic."

~ by Meadows Martin, from the book: 365 Days With Self-Discipline: 365 Life-Altering Thoughts on Self-Control, Mental Resilience, and Success

Check out Michael Hyatt Book, .... Free to Focus', 'I know this feeling so very well.

It comes from having promised yourself two very separate lives that canâ€™t really coexist.

When you were at your day job you thought about how much more productive you would be if only you could work full-time on YouTube.

You also likely daydreamed about how relaxing and free your day would be to have a lie in or be able to choose your own schedule.

These are opposites.

The truth is you will never be as productive with your time as when you worked a day job and had a solid focus on the small few hours you had control over.

As much as you loved that level of productivity it required a level of energy that wasnâ€™t sustainable and you dreamed of getting a break from.

This now leaves you unhappy with your level of productivity as you are free to do less but still unsatisfied that you are not achieving more.

You are also now getting backlash from the part of your mind that you promised would be allowed more of a rest.

You will resent the things that you have to get up for as your body says â€œI was promised this life would be more restful and itâ€™s notâ€.

That is the start of burn out. When your mind says no to the work you genuinely want it to do and simple tasks feel heavy.

The way around this is by recognising that one desire pulls you away from the other. Stop expecting both the most productive day & the most fun day at the same time.

You cannot achieve hard work & relaxation on the same day.

Balance can be found by having structured task focused hard-working early-start days that satisfy the productivity level you want. Challenge yourself to hit an ambitious outcome that is exciting, with the promise of a full rest afterwards.

Then follow this up with several zero work, fun only, guilt free wasteman days.

It creates a cycle of work & reward that is more in harmony and is more sustainable. It fulfils both needs without them competing.

You owe yourself a backlog of those rest days first.', 'These kinds of videos are still appreciated man ğŸ€ğŸ€', 'ğŸ€ The universe is a weird, weird entity, because Iâ€™ve spent the last few hours having an existential crisis about my workflow, output, goals and the general scheduling of my life, then as Iâ€™m resisting the urge to burst into tears, I see Aliâ€™s new video in my feed.

00:00 ğŸ“š Ali introduces the book "Building a Second Brain" by Tiago Forte as a solution to information overwhelm.

01:52 ğŸ¨ Discusses the historical use of commonplace books by creatives for capturing ideas.
02:22 ğŸ–¥ï¸ Advocates for a digital commonplace book to efficiently store and access information.
03:19 ğŸŒŸ Emphasizes the utility of a second brain for creatives in capturing and expressing ideas.
03:56 ğŸ¢ Connects the concept of a second brain to knowledge work, illustrating its relevance beyond creative fields.
04:41 ğŸ—‚ï¸ Introduces the CODE framework for building a second brain: Capture, Organize, Distill, Express.
05:09 ğŸ§  Shares the insight that the brain is for having ideas, not holding them, highlighting the benefits of externalizing memory.
06:11 ğŸ“’ Provides examples of what to capture in a second brain, from book highlights to personal musings.
08:31 ğŸ“‚ Details on organizing information by actionability rather than source or topic for effectiveness.
10:23 ğŸ” Discusses the importance of distilling information to its essence through progressive summarization.
11:48 ğŸ¤ Highlights expressing or sharing ideas as a crucial final step, applying knowledge in productive or creative ways.
13:09 ğŸ”„ Ali discusses the transition from viewing projects as "heavy lifts" to "slow burns," enabling work on multiple projects in parallel for increased productivity and creativity.
14:06 ğŸ“ˆ Explains how the second brain system allows for gradual progress on projects by incorporating relevant information over time, simplifying final assembly.
14:36 ğŸ« Shares how the second brain aids in quickly preparing for teaching and presentations, leveraging accumulated knowledge for rapid talk preparation.

Learn the money game and ger RICH !', 'When you free up your brain from remembering, enhancing thereby the work memory, you would think you have less stress and be able to focus on creating ideas. That's exactly what will happen, in fact, it will be so good that you start to produce tons of ideas. But then, eventually, there will be more ideas to act upon than there is time, meanwhile new ideas keep stacking up. Then eventually one ends up with the same amount of stress multiplied by at least ten times, because of brain explosion instead of brain implosion. So next stop, for me at least, is to optimize the organizational structure, but while doing that, even more new clever ideas still keep stacking up. \r
\r
Conclusion: In the end, the true way to survive is to have great ability to put things really into perspective and do lots of self-reflection. Even while I'm now trying to reduce the amount of information I myself produce, I still keep producing new information trying to figure out and understand how to actually do that.\r

00:00 Intro
-The problem of information overload leads to a need for a system to help manage and organize information.

-The "second brain" system helps solve the problem of information overload by providing a framework for organizing and storing information.

-The "second brain" system has helped Ali in his own life, and can hopefully help others as well.

-The "second brain" system uses CODE as an acronym to explain its core foundations - Capture, Organize, Distill, Express.

00:41 What is a Second Brain and why should you have one?
- A second brain is a digital system for capturing and organizing ideas.

- Building a second brain can help you express your creativity, be more productive and make better decisions.

- Every job today involves knowledge work of some kind, and a second brain can help you with inputting, processing, and outputting information.

- The methodology for building a second brain has four parts: Capture, Organize, Distill and Express (CODE).

04:56 C (Capture)
- Ali discusses different ways of capturing information, both manually and automatically.

-Ali captures his thoughts and ideas in Apple Notes.

- He also has a system for automatically capturing highlights from books, articles, and podcasts.

- Having a good capture system helps reduce stress levels by freeing up your brain from having to remember everything.

- Ali recommends using a note taking system to store thoughts and ideas that come to mind throughout the day, as well as highlights from books, articles, and podcasts.

08:32 O (Organise)
- Ali suggests organizing information by actionability rather than topic in order to be more targeted and efficient in one's learning.

- This means that when you come across something relevant, you add it to the project folder related to the action you plan to take, rather than creating a new category for it.

- You can still search for specific information using control F or command F if needed.

- This system is especially helpful when working on long-term projects with many moving parts.

11:07 D (Distill)
- Ali talks about a method called progressive summarization, which is basically like highlighting, but on steroids.

- This is effective for flagging up the areas which are particularly important.

- Different than highlighting we're used to in school - it's not particularly effective for retention in your own personal brain, but it is effective for flagging up the areas which are particularly important.

11:45 E (Express)
-The "E" in the second brain system stands for Express, meaning that once you have captured and organized your ideas, you need to share them with the world in some way.

-Sharing your ideas allows you to receive feedback, collaborate with others, and ultimately create something tangible that is the output of all of your hard work.

-Without expressing our ideas, they are essentially useless - it's important to find a way to share your creativity with others.

13:09 How my Second Brain has helped Ali
-The course/book has helped Ali become more productive, but also more creative and less stressed in general.

-The system taught Ali the idea of slow burns versus heavy lifts - working on multiple projects simultaneously so that when it comes time to actually finish one, most of the work is already done.

-The system has also helped with his teaching work - he can easily prepare talks with just a few minutes notice by referencing his stored information.', 'JUICE - GANGSTA

I started using Todoist around 2013 (to be fair - I love it, and i still use it). I quickly followed it by Evernote which acted mainly as my diary + "some useful stuff" / note taking app. Of course, at that moment, connecting notes / articles was clunky, one way, hashtags, categories, no backlinks. So sooner or later, only key / critical notes were actually useful (like ie. "packing-trip" list ;) ). Other always became more or less outdated.

Later, when all this backlinking hype started ;) - Roam etc. , I started using Obsidian. As a software engineer I liked it, because under the hood, it was a simple markdown editor. I liked it, yet ... creating notes, all these backlinks etc. was ... time consuming. It was not only about quickly writing down your thought(s), but also about thinking : "how can I later find it" (in this non-linear / second-brain). As a result - i prefered to quickly add a thought via todoist task - because i could do it in seconds, rather than full fledged backlinking obsidian article.

I ended up with:
- Todoist - for daily todo tasks
- Stackedit - random not that important notes using quick markdown notation articles (not connected with each other) - i like that it has built-in sync from every device that literally has just a browser (this is useful - if you have tablet, desktop, laptop, mobile phone, raspebery pi etc. - this is really nice, if you want to access your articles from everywhere, every device you have without installing third party apps)
- Notion - as a daily diary

I don't store my thoughts, ideas as second-brain anymore because i came to the conclusion that creating such notes, maintaing them, keeping them up to date, requires waay too much effort compared to simply finding the asnwer to the topic that interests you (via google / youTube) when ... YOU ACTUALLY NEED IT :) The benefit of it is that:
- the information you get is up to date
- you don't need to maintain it
- you don't need to spend time to create it

If i really need something hmm personal, i try to keep it minimal, keep it flat ie. i simply create a project in Todoist (like ie. computer games ideas) and write my ideas down as plain tasks.

\r
write the things down and form a second brain\r
\r
any interesting idea you get or a thought note it down\r
\r
take in the information and process it and then produce output. \r
\r
*CODE* system to organize your life\r
\r
1. capture it!\r
\r
Brain is for having ideas and not storing them\r
\r
any worthy thought you come across or a high yield quote , note it down\r
\r
1. Organize\r
\r
don't organize notes topic wise. For eg when taking notes on â€œhow to live longerâ€ or from a random self help book, rather than making separate folders on the note app , try to put them in a folder which is target oriented towards a particular goal\r
\r
don't be organization maniac when it comes to organizing your notes. Keep it simple so that you would actually access them in future without any effort involved\r
\r
1. Distal it !\r
\r
whatever notes you have taken , now actually go through them and make a sort of mental model. Apply the information learnt in a target oriented manner. Say you want to learn biochemistry. Rather than saying that I would study biochem today , say â€œI will learn how sodium potassium pumps work in cell membraneâ€. This way you are actually learn for application world. \r
\r
1. Express\r
\r
all the things captured by you is worthless unless you bring it out to people. Express your ideas to public and add value from their learnings to your life to your second brain.\r
\r

00:00 This video discusses actionable tips from the book "Someday is Today" by Matthew Dicks, offering practical advice for achieving more in life.
01:09 Tip 1: Embrace the "Parking Lot Practice" - True productivity doesn't have to look pretty; don't wait for the perfect environment to pursue creative work.
03:58 Tip 2: Adopt the "Minutes Mindset" - Value every minute, leapfrogging between tasks rather than focusing solely on hours, maximizing productivity in short timeframes.
06:50 Tip 3: Use the "Lily Pad Method" - Break down overwhelming goals into smaller tasks, jumping between them based on your mood and energy, fostering flexibility and progress.
09:42 Tip 4: Embrace the "Horizon Habit" - Set directional goals on the horizon instead of overly specific goals, promoting flexibility and resilience in achieving long-term aspirations.
11:22 Tip 5: Beware the "Piano Precedent" - Five-year plans can invite unexpected challenges; find a balance between planning and adapting to life's twists and turns.
12:31 Tip 6: Consider the "100-Year-Old Plan" - When at a crossroads, imagine advice from your 100-year-old self to prioritize what truly matters, providing a broader perspective on decision-making.
13:56 Tip 7: Embrace the "Purposeful Approach" - Productivity isn't just about work; define "soft goals" that bring meaning and satisfaction to your life, allowing time for what truly matters.

- Productivity doesn't have to look pretty.\r
- The importance of seizing any moment for creative work.\r
- Waiting for the perfect environment can lead to prolonged inaction.\r
- The timing is never perfect; the time to act is now.\r
\r
ğŸ’Š Minute's Mindset\r
- Values every minute, not just every hour.\r
- The idea of waiting for specific blocks of time and encourages intentional use of shorter periods.\r
- Emphasis on the value of small, intentional actions in achieving long-term goals.\r
\r
ğŸ’Š Lily Pad Method\r
- Encourages a non-linear approach to achieving goals.\r
- Breaking down tasks into "lily pads" allows for flexibility and progress even when feeling overwhelmed.\r
- Working on multiple projects simultaneously for flexibility and joy in the creative process.\r
\r
ğŸ’Š Horizon Habit\r
- As an alternative to SMART goals, focusing on what is within one's control.\r
- Setting goals that are realistic and relevant to one's journey prevents demotivation from factors outside of personal control.\r
- Demotivating nature of goals tied to external metrics (ex, Youtube Subscribers).\r
- Encourages setting goals that align with personal growth and progress rather than external measures of success.', 'Thank you ğŸ˜Š', 'Have you lost weight? 1. Productivity is not pretty: Overcome ideal environment dependency, e.g., the Parking Lot Story.
2. Embrace the minutes mindset: Get the most out of every minute, like when you are waiting at a restaurant.
3. The Lily Pad method: Tackle your projects in a non-linear fashion by working on any part you feel like at the moment to maintain momentum and reduce overwhelm.
4. Plan with horizon goals: Goals are just destinations; they shouldn't be a source of stress. This also leads to the idea that horizon goals, such as becoming a writer and doing other billion things related to writing, give you both freedom and resilience.
5. Five-year plans are inviting the universe to drop a piano on you: When you plan everything, it's bound to have something go wrong. You have your plans on one axis and fate on the other, and the path your life takes is sort of somewhere between these two lines. So, think of plans as these dots on a chart that you will sometimes touch upon.
6. The Solomon Project: Spend time journaling with your older self to reflect on what matters to you, to reveal what you want your legacy to be, and your long-term plans.
7. The Purposeful Approach: Be productive for the sake of maximizing fun, work, and relationships. Don't just think of it in terms of economic output.

After watching this I realized I have so much time.', 'Thank you for your videos, Ali. â¤', 'SUMMARY\r
1. *The Parking Lot Practice*: Don't wait for the perfect environment to work on your creative projects. Take action despite imperfect conditions, and don't let the lack of an ideal setting hold you back.\r
\r
2. *The Minutes Mindset*: Embrace shorter periods of time as opportunities to be productive. Use those small pockets of time during the day to make progress on your goals instead of waiting for longer, uninterrupted hours.\r
\r
3. *The Lily Pad Method*: Instead of tackling your goals sequentially, consider them as lily pads, and jump between them based on your motivation and energy levels. This approach allows for flexibility and prevents feeling overwhelmed.\r
\r
4. *The Horizon Habit*: Set horizon goals rather than overly specific ones. These are directional goals that provide flexibility, allowing you to adapt and pursue different avenues within a broader focus.\r
\r
5. *The Piano Precedent*: When faced with choices, consider what advice your 100-year-old self would give. This perspective helps you prioritize meaningful experiences and relationships over immediate productivity.\r
\r
6. *The Purposeful Approach*: Productivity doesn't always have to relate to work or economic output. Identify "soft goals" that bring you personal satisfaction and meaning, even if they may not appear productive to others.\r
\r
7. *The 100-Year-Old Plan*: Imagine yourself at 100 years old to gain long-term perspective and make decisions that align with your future self's advice, focusing on what truly matters in life.', 'Hi, do you know the name of the book in Spanish ?', 'Iâ€™m crying. Lol', '7 Actionable Ways to Achieve More in Life:
1 - The Parking Lot Practice: there's no perfect place to be productive, just do it;\r
2 - The Minutes Mindset: use every single minute you have;\r
3 - The Lilypad Method: think about steps you can jump, start in the middle (in medias res);\r
4 - The Horizon Habit: set goals but not so specific;

The video is about how to be more disciplined. The speaker, Ali Abdaal, who is a doctor turned entrepreneur, introduces five science-backed methods to achieve this goal.

The first method is mental contrasting, which involves contrasting your present reality with your desired future to create a sense of urgency and motivation. The second method is implementation intentions, which involves creating if-then statements to plan how you will overcome obstacles that might hinder you from achieving your goals.

The third method is reducing environmental friction, which involves designing your environment to make it easier to do the things you want to do and avoid the things you don't want to do. The fourth method is monitoring and tracking, which involves tracking your progress to stay motivated and make adjustments as needed.

The fifth method is finding ways to make what you're doing more enjoyable or energizing. This can involve incorporating play, power, and people into your activities to make them more fun and engaging.

Overall, the video emphasizes that discipline is not about willpower, but about creating systems and habits that make it easier to do the things you want to do. By following these five methods, you can become more effortlessly disciplined and achieve your goals.', 'ğŸ¥°ğŸ˜ğŸ˜ğŸ¥°ğŸ¥°ğŸ¥°ğŸ¥°', 'Everytime Ali Abdaal releasing a Video, it makes my day. Thank u Ali', 'Whoever edits these videos - love your work!', 'If you're short on time, here's a quick summary of the valuable information Ali shared in this video!

1. Mental contrasting. Recognizing the difference between our current state and our desired state makes it easier for us to act in ways conducive to reaching our goal.

2. Implementation Intentions or habit-stacking. Obstacles are bound to arise; developing a tangible plan for overcoming foreseeable challenges is a great way to keep moving.

3. Environment design. Whether you are having trouble dieting or getting work done, create an environment that moves the marker in your direction. A typical example would be keeping candy out of your house if you're trying to eat healthier.

4. Time management and tracking. Tracking our behavior is eye-opening to how we are truly spending our time. It's scientifically proven that by creating a quantitative awareness of our goals, we can increase motivation, create feedback loops, and improve clarity. [Bonus: use an app called Streaks!]

5. Make your work enjoyable. Getting yourself to do something you know drains your energy is much more work. You can remove friction by adding enjoyable elements to your work; find some way to romanticize your life.

- Reflect on life in three segments: work, health, relationships.\r
- Break each segment into three components (e.g., health: body, mind, soul).\r
- Rate satisfaction or alignment on a scale of 0 to 10 for each component.\r
- Create a visual representation (radar chart) of the ratings.\r
- Add a category for joy and rate alignment in actions with joy.\r
- Identify areas needing improvement and set goals for alignment.\r
- Regularly use the Wheel of Life for self-reflection.\r
\r
ğŸ’Š Method 2: 12-Month Celebration\r
- Imagine celebrating progress in various life areas 12 months from now.\r
- Identify specific goals for each area, focusing on one primary goal.\r
- Add the phrase "while enjoying every step along the way" to each goal.\r
- Write down goals and regularly review them to stay focused.\r
- Consider the why behind each goal to reinforce motivation.\r
- Attend a live online workshop on January 6th, 2024, by pre-ordering the book.\r
\r
ğŸ’Š Method 3: Ideal Week Method\r
- Create an ideal week calendar, blocking time for essential activities.\r
- Determine the time available for personal goals after essential blocks.\r
- Align personal goals with available time, adjusting as needed.\r
- Prioritize and allocate time for activities related to the 12-month celebration.\r
- Embrace flexibility and adapt goals based on available time.\r
- Attend the live online workshop on January 6th, 2024, by pre-ordering the book.', 'Congratulations Ali!

Ali give Him a chance !!!', 'Notes to video:

Give answers to these in written form!
Method 1: Serve the World
1) Imagine a TED conference where the speaker inspires everyone, including yourself. The speaker ist you, 20 years in the future.
- What are you talking about, and what's so inspiring about it?
not necessarily world changing, but can be!

2) The talent Service Prompt
Imagine a world where you have all the money and all the time. How would you use your talents and skills to serve others?
- What are your natural talents
- What would be sustainable
3) The Eulogy Prompt
Visualise the eulogy at your funeral, where your friends and family are saying nice things about you. But what would people positively impatec by your work say?

Method 2: Reduce Fear
1) The Fearless Dream Prompt
What would you do, if you knew you could not fail at it?
- Category: health, work, relationships
- What do you want to learn/try/experiment with?
- What impact would I like to have
2) The Fail-Proof Dream Prompt
What would you like to do, even if oyu knew you would fail at it?
what process would you enjoy experiencing? (Rather than just the results of it)

3) The Deferred Dream Prompt
What's one dream you've always had but never pursued? Why is it a dream for you? What is stopping you from persuing it?

Method 3: What's your Dream Life?
1) The Ideal Tuesday Prompt
What does your ideal ordinary Tuesday look like?
What are you doing?
Who are you with?
How are you spending your time?
What makes this day perfect for you?
Imagine it being a year from now?
2) The Future Self Prompt
Imagine you've achieved everything you've ever wanted. How have you changes as a person? What qualities and achievements define this future version of yourself?

Method 4: Other People
The Role Model Prompt
Who are the people you most admire, and why?
What qualities do the posses that you wish to emulate?
If you were an amalgamation of 3-5 people you admire, who would they be, and what would you want to emulate about them?

Method 5: The End in Mind
The Obituary Writing Prompt
What would it look like if you wrote out your own obituary?
- Categories: Relationships, Work, Achievements

There have been many times in my life, for either myself or my children, that we needed urgent medical care, it couldnâ€™t wait until morning or until Monday, but we didnâ€™t need an emergency either, we just needed to see a doctor right away. So we greeted our teeth, and clutched our wallet and headed to the ER (where we really didnâ€™t need or want to be, and definitely didnâ€™t want to pay for $150 urgent care vs $4,000 ER for the same treatment). Had there been an urgent care clinic open in the middle of the night I would have gone there.
So hereâ€™s how it would work. Patients come in. They see a receptionist (who has enough medical training to tell the difference between those needing urgent care vs emergency care and then directs them where they need to go. This should take a fair amount of strain off of emergency rooms, especially during flu season. And if someone happens to go in for something that seems minor but turns out to be major, well they are still right next to the emergency room, and they can either quickly wheel them over, or call the ER for help. Honestly it would also be a good idea to have a separate area just for infections patients too, so that way people having strokes and heart attacks also wonâ€™t get COVID or influenza while they are in the waiting room or ER. There should also be a nurse or emt assigned just to the waiting room. They can even start administering care if needed. There have been several times I have gone to the ER because I couldnâ€™t breath (asthma), or anxiety attacks, sometimes both, and I honestly thought I was going to die right there in the waiting room. Unfortunately when you are young, people never seem to think your emergency are as urgent as older peopleâ€™s. Also get some bed in the waiting room! 05:12 ğŸ“ Prioritization is key: focus on what truly matters by recognizing that you can't do everything, and learn to say no to low-priority tasks.
09:38 ğŸ”„ Balance life maintenance with progress: allocate time daily for activities that actively move you forward in work, health, or relationships.
13:40 ğŸ§˜ Cultivate intentionality: periodically assess your activities to ensure they align with your intentions, fostering a habit of mindful time usage.
14:37 ğŸ•°ï¸ Intentionality is key in time management; aim for every 15-minute block to be intentional, whether productive or leisure.
15:20 ğŸ§­ Setting goals for the year helps create a sense of progress and purpose beyond daily routines.
16:31 â±ï¸ Even small blocks of time, like 15 minutes, can be valuable for making progress on important projects or relationships.
17:41 ğŸ¤– Treat yourself like a system; analyze failures or lapses in productivity without self-criticism and adjust strategies accordingly.

- Encourages setting goals and working towards them,
- Highlights the importance of achieving a sense of purpose outside of work.
09:38 ğŸ§˜\u200dâ™‚ï¸ The Mindset of Intentionality
- Introduces the concept of intentionality in time management,
- Draws parallels with mindfulness practices,
- Emphasizes the value of being deliberate and conscious in daily actions.
13:54 â³ Time Management Concept
- Time management is about being intentional with how time is used.
- Intentionality is key to effective time management.
- The goal is to ensure every time block is intentionally utilized, whether for work or leisure activities.
16:03 ğŸ¤– Treating Yourself Like a System
- Treating oneself like a system involves analyzing failures objectively.
- Adjusting behaviors based on understanding the reasons behind failure.
- It's about tweaking the system rather than self-criticism.
20:01 ğŸ¯ Setting Personal Goals
- Importance of having personal goals outside of work for effective time management.
- Having clear goals provides motivation and direction.
- Goals should be meaningful and go beyond mere life maintenance.

Important for brain, health and fresh ideas. Instead making your life about using every minute perfect.', 'I really like this series, canâ€™t wait for episode 3! â˜ºï¸', 'Hi! I was addicted to YouTube and random scrolling for 10 years. I am not anymore. Here is how I did it and you can to:
I made this tool to keep myself accountable. It takes 30 days to rewire the brain, so I drew a house on a piece of paper with 30 windows in it. In each window, I wrote something inspiring like "you are making more money in less time", "you are feeling pure-minded"', find the most desirable sentences for you. Every day before bed, I would paint the window green If I succeeded and red if I did not. You must be absolutely strict with yourself, otherwise it can not work. So, If i would watch half an IG reel, that would be a "red day". Its incredible just how badly you will want to paint that window green and not red.
Other points that can help you:
- To our brain, everything is relative, If you have your work open in one desktop and entertainment on the other, you are likely to choose the latter. So, to avoid unintentional entertainment simply remove it. You can use browser extensions that hide things like recommended videos and shorts.
- Short form content is diabolic. It's made to be addictive and I realised if I let myself watch it for a few minutes, in a week it will turn into a few hours. So I never watch it, and so should you.
- This is your life now. Its not a detox, its not temporary, so build a system which is sustainable for yourself. For example, I always allow myself watch channels that I am subscribed to, but none of them are addicitive entertainment, they all are educational. Find nieches on YT that only inspire you and give you energy and cut the rest. No recommended feed, ever.
- Limiting time does not work, at all. Limit the content instead. Its like saying, I will be a crack addict only for 15 minutes a day. If you allow yourself even a little bit, you will have urges all day and dealing with them is stressful. However, if you quit the addictive behavior completely, you will stop feeling this tension overtime.
- If your life is empty, it is naturall to fill the void with unintentional entertainment. You may feel this void very strongly, and it can be painfull in the beginning, and that is great. Now, to succesfully replace addictive garbage with real life, slowly start adding real activities: fitness, hobbies, friendship, romance, etc. If you do not, it is going to feel empty and you will be constantly tempted to fall back into addiction.\xa0

We all just want to live. All entertainment is an illusory replacement of doing things. You are normal, you have good intentions, but most of us have fallen to this trap, coming from sillicon valley, that made us to believe it is ok to reduce human experience to scrolling. Now our responsibility is to get out.

I believe in you, best of luck, you really can do this.', 'Hi Ali, I really like watching your videosâ¤', 'I started the habit of not watching TV during ramadan & yes: it frees a lot of time for everything else.

Thanks and lots of love â¤â¤â¤â¤', 'in brief: The video discusses effective time management strategies, emphasizing the importance of developing specific skills to improve how one manages their time. Here's a summary of the key points:\r
1. *Prioritization:* Ali stresses the importance of prioritizing tasks and activities based on their importance and impact on one's goals. He advises against using the phrase "I don't have time" and instead suggests evaluating what activities are truly a priority. Practical tips include setting clear goals, utilizing daily adventures to identify the most important task for the day, and conducting weekly reviews to assess and plan priorities.\r
\r
2. *Time Blocking:* This technique involves allocating specific blocks of time in one's calendar for various tasks, including work, personal activities, and leisure. Ali describes time blocking as a crucial skill for ensuring that important tasks are given dedicated time slots, thus enhancing focus and productivity.\r
\r
3. *Focus:* Developing the ability to focus is highlighted as essential for effective time management. Ali suggests that improving focus involves practicing single-tasking and reducing distractions. He recommends resources and strategies for enhancing one's ability to focus, such as reading relevant books and participating in focus improvement courses.\r
\r
4. *Follow-Through:* The skill of actually doing what one plans to do is discussed as critical for successful time management. Ali talks about the challenges of procrastination and the importance of overcoming them through clarity, courage, and starting tasks. He also emphasizes the role of accountability, both personal and external, in ensuring follow-through on commitments.\r
\r
5. *Energizing Your Work:* Finally, Ali touches on the importance of finding ways to energize one's work to prevent burnout and maintain high energy levels. He suggests incorporating elements of play, leveraging personal power, and engaging with people to make work more enjoyable and energizing.\r
\r
Throughout the video, Ali provides personal insights, practical tips, and resources to help viewers manage their time more effectively, emphasizing the goal of not just being more productive but also leading a balanced and fulfilling life.gpt4', 'What to do if you really struggle with time blocking?
